726631f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Roosevelt Avenue - Flushing Bay.]
726631f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Three views in a southeasterly
direction across the north end of the park lying between Roosevelt
Avenue and Flushing Bay. This area is being constructed into large
automobile parking spaces for visitors to the New York World's Fair
1939-40. In the background is the I. R. T. and B. M. T. subway
''g;'' on Roosevelt Avenue; in the foregound is Grand Central Parkway
(view 2) and on the extreme left (view 3) is Northern Boulevard
and Flushing Bay. In the distant background is Flushing.
October 21, 1936
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

726604f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Mill Pond.]
726604f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Viewing north across the
hmeadows and Mill Pond, at the eastern extremity of the park,to-
ward a small community clustered around Willow Street and Fowler
Avenue, seen from Rodman Street at North Hempstead Turnpike.
This area later became part of the main exposition center of the
New York World's Fair of 1939-40. The Court of Peace and the

726672f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - New York World's Fair of 1939-40 - [Industrial exhibits.]
726672f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Cueens): Three of the industrial
exhibits at the New York World's Fair 1939-40, situated in the
southeast corner of the main exposition center. View 1 shows
the Du Pont Build'ng, ''The Wonder World of Chemistry,'' the de-
signer of which is Walter Dorwin Teague; view 2, the General
Electric Company Building. Voorhees, Walker, Foley and Smith
are the architects; view 3, the Petroleum Industry Building,
the roof of which is painted blue and is illuminated at night
with fluorescent tubes.
June 16, 1940
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODTTTIONS

726679f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - New York World's Fair of 1939-40 -[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics Pavilion.]
726679f-a.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Cueens): The pavilion of the Union
of Soviet Socialist Republics (Russiaw) at the New York Vorlda
Fair 1939-40, seen across the Lagoon of Nstions. Atop the tower
of marble and porphyry at the entrance to the building is a stain-
less steel figure, designed by Vyacheslav Andreev, depicts the
spirit of bhe Souiet worker. It weighs thirty tons and forms,
after the Trylon--the Worldtc Fair theme--the highest spet at the
Fair. Architects of the pavilion are Boris N. Iofan and Karo S.
Alabian. On the two wings of the puilding are reliefs of Stalin
(left) and Lenin.
May 29, 1939
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRCDTCTIONS

728262f-c.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Interboro Rapid Transit Carbarn.]
728262f-c.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (2ueens): A train of old Brooklyn Ash
Removal Company cars in the northern portion of the park, before
this area was transformed into part of the grounds of the New
York World's Fair 1939-40. In the right background are the I. R. T.
ear barns.
View 2 is toward the Roosevelt Avenue subway and vehicular
bridge over the Flushing River.
View 3 shows the same area being developed for the World's
Fair. Note the I. R. T. car barns.
View 1: September 30, 1935
View 2: October 5, 1935
View 3: October 18, 1936
P. L. Sperr

726602f-c.text:

from Rodman Street and North Hempstead Turnpike. In the fore-
ground is Mill Pond and the winding Flushing Creek. This area

subway ''El'' under construction in the background.
1925

726702f-a.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [New York World's Fair of 1939-40 - New York World's Fair Administration Building.]
726702f-a.text:
Completed Adminstration Building of the
New York World's Fair 1939 which becase ready
today (Trday) for occupancy on Monday by a
force of 600 employes who are being transferred
from the Empire State Building over the week-
end. Construction of the Administration
Building, at the site in Flushing Meadow,
Uueens, was completed in the record time of
124 days. Ihe cost was approximately 1900,Lwu.
''This picture is sent to you for publication only
and must not be used for advertising or comercial
purposes without written permission from New York
World's Pair 1939 Incorporated.'

726663f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Shown, in a set of three views,
is the monumental George Washingto) by the sculptor James Earle
Fraser, and a group of small figures called 'The Moods of Time,''
by Paul Manship. The .ashington statue stands at the west end of
Constitution Mall, is sixty-five feet high ad includes a fifteen-
foot base. 'The Moods of Tiwe'' depict morning, dav, evening, and
night. Seen from right to left they are: morning, night, day, and
evening.
May 29, 1939
Views 1,2,3

726663f-c.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [New York World's Fair of 1939-40.]
726663f-c.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Shown, in a set of three views,
is the monumental George Washingto) by the sculptor James Earle
Fraser, and a group of small figures called 'The Moods of Time,''
by Paul Manship. The .ashington statue stands at the west end of
Constitution Mall, is sixty-five feet high ad includes a fifteen-
foot base. 'The Moods of Tiwe'' depict morning, dav, evening, and
night. Seen from right to left they are: morning, night, day, and
evening.
May 29, 1939
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

726673f-c.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - New York World's Fair of 1939-40 - [Industrial exhibits; Communications Building; National Cash Register Company; United States Steel Corporation.]
726673f-c.text:
Flushing Seadow Park (Cueens): Three of the industrial
exhibits at the New York World's Fair of 1939-40. View 1 shows
the National Cash Register Company Building; view 2, the Com-
munications Building, the architects of which are Francis Keally
and Leonard Dean. A mural by Eugene Savage shows an Indian
smoke signal and nude muses. Two 150-foot pylons adorn both
sides of the entrance. View 3 is the TInited States Steel Corp.
Building. It appropriately has its steel framework outside the
shell of the structure. The architects are York and Sawyer.
View 1: June 21, 1940
View 2: May 29, 1939
View 3: June 16, 1940
F. L. Sperr
NNO REPODUCTIO S

726620f-b.title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park.
726620f-b.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): A former golf club house on
the east aide of 111th Street and 46th Avenue, which was later
razed when the area was improved as part of the New York Worldts
Fair grounds. The Railroads exhibit building was later erected
here. View 2 is south on 111th Street from 45th Avenue.
November 2, 1936
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
